text: Physician Assisted Suicide is the actual term for this going back a long time. Its not some right wing invention.

Flipside of that is I've met a few dickheads who wanted to "euthanise" their pets for highly questionable reasons, such as feeling over their pet as soon as it gets old and needs some kind of care eg thyroid pills.

I agree. I think the right to end our own life should  be included among our most sacred and profound. I don't think it should, or will in time, end up just being restricted to just the terminally ill either.
Not even sure why this is controversial. We treat our pets better than our family.

Yes, painless and quite fast actually. I work in an industry where we are trained about low oxygen environment risks. Containers purged of hydrocarbon vapours using nitrogen, for example. It essentially takes one good breath to become unconscious. Nitrogen is odourless, tasteless, and already makes up the majority of the air we breathe. Your body would likely keep breathing for a time, but you would be blissfully unaware that your brain was being starved of oxygen until your death, likely in minutes. As an aside to the dangers of inert atmospheres, nearly half of all workplace fatalities where a person has succumbed to either low O2 or a toxic vapour are the result of a failed rescue attempt. Our first instinct on seeing a coworker (likely a friend) in trouble is to rush in to help.

It's hard, but sometimes it's the right thing to do. Putting my first dog down hurt, but was right. He was in pain. My kitty passed naturally, just shy of 20, in July. I built her a little wood ramp so she could get on her sleeping spot. She couldn't jump up anymore
I would always rather say goodbye one day too soon, than let them suffer one day too long.
Out of curiosity, couldn't somebody with a diagnosed terminal illness forsee their need for assisted suicide and move to Oregon before they become incapable of doing so?
Having ALS is different than "having to pay bills".  I'm not talking about health related issues.

There are plenty of religious people who are against it. And an overhwelming majority of our politicians are religious (or at least pretend to be).  Also note it's not illegal everywhere. Oregon, Washington and Vermont allow it. Though it's not really physician assisted as it's still illegal for a physician to do it, however it's NOT illegal for physician to prescribe a lethal dose of barbiturates for the express purpose of ending your life, provided you are of sound mind, request it twice in writing and have been diagnosed with a terminal illness with less than 6 months to live.
Does the nineteen year old have a terminal illness and appear to be reaching the end of their life? No? Well, no assisted suicide for them, then.

As absolutely harsh as it sounds, don't delay the inevitable. The way this goes, she will be with you and know that you are there for her.  It's so, so hard to lose them, but being a pet owner means doing the right thing, even when it breaks your heart.
Sometimes, when someone is sick for a long time, you do your grieving before they die, too. By the time they actually go, you've already been through the worst of it.
Watching someone you love die is hard. It's fucking awful. Deciding to help them go painlessly and without pointless lingering isn't so hard...from my experience.
When you're too stupid to realize you were going to suffer too. It's just too easy with those guys.

Like carrying a weight so great that your bones begin to crack. It's not that you choose to drop it, it's a matter of how long it takes for you to collapse. Whether you drop it now or wait until your body snaps, the end result is always the same. The weight comes down.

That's not whataboutism. Whataboutism is more about accusing your opponent of hypocrisy.  His opinion is based on the idea that people can make completely free decisions. I disagree with that idea, so I disagree with his opinion.

Your vet should be honoring your wish to not let the dog suffer one more day. Please take her to a real vet. Not one who thinks by doing 24 hr care, constantly, like a veterinary hospital at home is the answer.  The greatest gift we can give our unconditional love dogs is to never allow them to suffer.  I'm with you in thought and prayers that this 2nd opinion brings you both relief.

So because humans are "superior" we deserve cruel treatment where we would offer compassion to "inferior" animals? That argument doesn't make any sense. Torturing someone is not honouring them, or showing them compassion. I probably wouldn't torture Hitler if I had the chance, let alone innocent people who just want their suffering to end.

My dad was suffering from cancer. If this option was available, I could have seen him choose this route, rather than just becoming incapable of doing anything and soon going into a vegetative state where he could still suffer and feel pain. The only option was to take morphine but that doesn't always work. And you still feel the suffering and pain.

The article makes clear doctors have been able to administer lethal doses of narcotics since 2005.  I don't see what the big deal is about.  These people were clearly able to pass peacefully.  The problem with euthanasia is it leads to all kinds of dark places.  I respect that people aught to be able to do what they want when it comes to their own death, but what about when you have someone who is not capable of reasoning well, who has left no clear directions, and is either  ward of the state or worse, is sitting on an estate and the supposed decision makers have something to gain from their passing? What then?

We absolutely should invest in advancing care, and many other things.  Good thing we have MAID now so people who don't want to live (and are dying) aren't forced to take up all the resources needed to keep them alive when they have no reasonable chance of recovery.

Your position is the reason it's a conscious vote.  Its like abortion. It's not something we like to think about, and there are big ethical dilemmas involved (although both sides tend to believe it's black and white). I am personally pro-choice on both fronts, but I recognise the alternative view is not demonstrably "wrong", because it's not as simple as right or wrong. The devil is very much in the detail.
Going out on your own terms is the last way you can beat your illness.

are you OK with people swallowing a bottle of pills, cutting their wrists, injecting themselves with questionable stuff, sitting in a garage with the car running, shooting themselves, etc sometimes dying slowly and painfully, or making a mess of it so they live, but are badly messed up after?   Because thats what happens when people don't have quick painless choice that works.

Forgoing life extending treatment is not the same as withholding food and water from someone, which is more like what passive euthanasia is.  If a person chooses not to, say, accept cancer treatment because there is no hope anyway and they may as well enjoy what little time they have left without chemo and radiation, that's one thing. That's refusing life extending techniques, and that's fine. It's when someone is in a coma and their family has the intravenous feeding stopped so someone withers to death over days and weeks that's passive euthanasia... and if you're going to make a decision like that and kill someone, kill them quickly and mercifully instead, I say.

What do you do about an old relative being forced into feeling like they should kill themselves if they feel like a burden on their family? Or what if they are being pushed into doing it? I'm not against euthanasia, I'm just interested in the possible issues that it brings up.
In Canada medically assisted dying for the terminally ill has been legal since 2016. Conservatives use polls like these to try and use it as a wedge issue for upcoming elections.
You're not asking for permission to die, you're asking for them to give someone else permission  to kill you. There's an important distinction there.
The difference is I don't know the person I'm saving is innocent or guilty, in this scenario I know they're guilty, and thus I have no reason to save them
"People don't commit suicide because of sadness. They do it because they don't want to be in pain anymore."

I personally feel the undergirding foundation is greed over human dignity. In this way it would be another human alive, another dollar out of them.

Wikipedia says most locked in syndrome people can blink their eyes. I'd consider a video of him blinking out a request in Morse code to be a "written request." The problem with these one size fits all laws is that they leave no room for discretion.
I shouldn't say "I think" rather than "in my opinion" and "from the literature and studies I have read". And you're welcome to disagree.
The problem with euthanasia is that it can have severe complications that are likely to lead to death.

That's my view. I think people have the right to dignified suicide. I don't have the right to determine whether or not a person is "justified" in assisted suicide. The only exception I would make is for criminals who are incarcerated and have not completed their sentence.
I'm just coming back here to say that the veterinarian said this was absolutely the issue. I was able to speak with him more in detail at her euthanasia appointment.

It is not evil. He has been completely paralyzed for over a decade and has wanted to commit suicide for a long time. Forcing him to continue living is cruel. As someone with mental health issues, fuck you. Prolonged suffering is cruelty.

I don't see the contraction with assisted suicide and assisted support either. As I said, the problem is expanding the program to people who would choose to live if they were given the proper support and resources. The first option above all should be our government investing and focusing on the support piece above all, and making this a last resort

I had a thoracotomy over a decade ago. Through various errors and medical issues, I ended up being without pain relief over night at one point. By the time my parents came in to see me in the morning (and therefore had someone available capable of ralling the doctors to help) I was in so much pain that I literally just wanted to die. Every second was an eternity of pain that I could not escape from.  The pain doctor pumped me so full of morphine I was out of it for a long time after but those hours in pain fucked me up royally. It took a long time for me to come back from the despair such pain sent me into.  I have always been pro-voluntary euthanasia but that night cemented my opinions on the subject. Those few hours were not life. They were torture.

this is weirdly comforting... my dad had a legit terminal disease where it was difficult for him to breathe and they had him on lots of opioids at the end. he was so miserable before this and I couldn't tell whether the drugs were really helping or if he was scared and in pain and just couldn't tell us because the drugs were knocking him out (never really done opiates). Knowing it's likely that he was blissed out before he died really helps.  glad you are still here though
Ugh, some humans are garbage and should never be entrusted with the care of another living being.
I assume that everyone here in favour of euthanasia is willing to push the syringe and perform the act.
In Oregon you no longer need to be a resident to use Compassion and Choices

I have a disability as does my closest friend. I am grateful that MAiD exists. But that's also because I work in healthcare and have experience in a residential hospice facility. When you see that side, you become very aware there are fates worse than death. Providing social assistance and MAiD should not be seen as competing causes. Rather than argue to deny bodily autonomy you just focus on improving social assistance. I find it offensive as a disabled person, that anyone, activist or not, is trying to take what control I do have for my situation. It's honestly no different than when religious wing nuts cry about MAiD being a sin. Both are trying to force their uneducated, discriminatory behaviour on others. Like abortion, if you don't agree with it, feel free to pass on using that option. No one is being forced into MAiD.
Right in the feels. People should be allowed to die if they want to, there are so many long, painful ways to die which you wouldn't wish on any one, why should people be forced to suffer?

I heard an npr interview of a US woman who brought her husband to Switzerland to be euthanized because he was suffering from dementia. They had agreed to the procedure well before the advanced stages while he was still cognizant. Anyways, I guess that qualifies as a mental illness, but it's a fat cry from garden variety depression or anxiety.

The thing that makes no sense to me is why are we even against it? If some asshole wants to jump across the Grand Canyon on a fucking unicycle probably to his death we televise that shit.  But if someone wants to go in a medically safe and pain free way. FUCK NO

My great aunt was diagnosed with ALS and within 18 months was a shell of her former self. It was incredibly hard on my grandfather to watch his twin waste away. She chose MAID before it got too bad, and was able to pass away with dignity. People deserve that.

So I do see both sides of the argument here. That being said, I've thought about being in the position myself, and I would totally give prior consent, and would want to go even though I'm sure I'd be scared to death of going through with it (budum tss)

The shame of it is almost every hospital in VT has just issued internal policies forbidding doctors practicing in their facilities from engaging in this practice, making it impossible for almost everyone to utilize it. We have a similar problem with DNR DNI end of life policies. Basically, you can have a written end of life wish, be holding it in your hand, wearing an alert bracelet when you get wheeled into an emergency room, and a family member you haven't heard from in thirty years can reverse it by threatening to sue the Dr or hospital if they don't do everything. Enjoy spending the last weeks of your life being tortured on a ventilator in an ICU somewhere.

What's funny is palliative care is literally just slowly overdosing a terminal patient (in their terminal phase) on opioids so they don't even feel the fact their body is shutting down and knocking them out as they're dying. My dad was one of the few oncologists in his cancer centre to decline working on assisted dying because essentially palliative care is literally just slowly killing someone without them realising it, way more tasteful than literally just killing yourself

Even though I'm one of the happiest people I've met, I completely agree with you. Life has no meaning if you don't give them a meaning, and it's all subjective. Therefore, you should have the right to end it whenever, just like we get births to be "assisted" free of charge, IVF, etc.

There's still the "must have less than 6 months to live" part, which is kind of ridiculous, since nobody knows how long you will live.  Some people are given 6 months then go on to live for many years, while others die of a heart attack in less than a minute.

"No-kill" rescues will turn away dogs because they are at capacity or because the dog isn't adoptable. That doesn't actually save the lives of any dogs. Around me, they avoid using the term "no-kill," but they still only euthanize if that's what is best for the dog (which includes significant behavioral issues which would make them unadoptable).

Not what I said, nor should that be your takeaway if you are interested in reasonable discourse. You should note my original comment was literally an appeal not to try to oversimplify complex problems and systems at the scale of entire societies and yet you have done so twice now.

I put down my rabbit last month. He was perfectly healthy except for a super aggressive cancer. He was getting worse but still seemed to really enjoy things. Being pet, banana, lounging etc. My vet said he might have some quality of life left but do you really want to wait until all he knows is suffering? I miss him. My life feels incomplete without him. Idon't enjoy playing my switch or PS5 without him. But it was the right decision.
That's obviously awful, but it doesn't mean MAID should be scrapped. There are people suffering who need access to it.

Which is why such laws should require a psychiatric evaluation as a prerequisite. I don't know about the Vermont law, but in Washington where I live the death with dignity law requires the approval of two different psychiatrists.
It might not be, but he shouldn't have to resort to this to end his life. He should be able to be in a room surrounded by his loved ones as he says goodbye.
Why do people automatically assume that death is better even than the most painful states of life? What if it isn't?

Watched my step father spend 30 days suffering from gangrene because of poor blood circulation. They took one leg during the first week and then the gangrene spent the next 3 weeks taking the other leg. All while he was fully aware and feeling the pain. On the last day, a nurse took my mother aside and told her to go get a bite to eat. While she was gone, they probably over dosed him on morphine. My mom got back to the hospital just in time to say good bye.
We treat our pets better than we treat each other in this respect.  Once you eliminate the absurdity of worrying about a "soul" or an "afterlife", these decisions become much more clear.

My Aunt died of cancer. It started in her foot, she suffered through chemo, only for the Drs to decide that they needed to amputate her foot, and half way to her knee. A month after that, they discovered the cancer had spread faster than they thought and it was now in her lungs, she suffered a long and agonizing death. I would absolutely chose the pod over that.
If I had a kid with a disability that severe I know I'd abort it.

I had a family member with a terminal illness who chose MAID.  In the 3 years that she was sick, no one ever pushed her towards it, and they never ever made her feel badly for taking every treatment possible, and living as long as she could.  MAID let her avoid spending her last days in pain or drugged into being a vegetable.  No one ever pushed it.  She chose, and they always, always, always told her that she had other options.
This will take time, I am hoping it is legal in 50 years when I live long enough that this will effect me directly.

I agree. I think the right to end our own life should  be included among our most sacred and profound. I don't think it should, or will in time, end up just being restricted to just the terminally ill either.

Honestly I'm not so much on board with the "its for their good their life would just be suffering" unless that suffering involves something like literally no conscious brain function. I don't think downs babies should be aborted all the time, but I understand that having a kid like that is a lifetime commitment and I could never fault someone for backing out of raising that kid.

I'm against it. Similar to how many people against the death penalty aren't against the it in theory but believe that even one innocent life being killed is too many and that the potential for miscarriage of justice is too high, I think the potential for abuse is too high to legalize it.
So they are treating this poor thing only to schedule it to be euthanased? Like wtf.

As someone who has tried to kill themselves I disagree. I don't think people who want to kill themselves(From mental conditions) are in a state of mind that can be trusted. At the time I would regularly stay awake for days straight causing hallucinations and memory lapses to the point where I can barely remember a six month stretch of my life. Not to mention the self medication. People like how I was can't and shouldn't be able to make that decision. However people with terminal illnesses and the such should be able to in my opinion.
Check out Danielle McKinnon on Instagram or YouTube. She is an animal communicator who talks a lot about euthanasia and animals passing. She says they let us know when they are ready to go.

the downvote parade hit you hard for a very good response. Death is only a horrid thing because people refuse to talk about it or accept that it will come some day. It's normal, enjoy the life you have don't let the fear of death ruin your existence.

If the government made life intolerable for you, don't use the government to end your life when you can easily do that yourself. Just my opinion. The government should have to do the opposite of this.

The issue is not necessarily a diagnosed mental illness but an undiagnosed one. You don't want to open the door to anyone having access to medically assisted suicide because that could lead to someone with an undiagnosed mental illness (like depression or extreme paranoia) wanting to take their own life without being able to actually provide informed consent. It also means that with the proper medical attention they could live a healthy, happy and productive life. it can also be argued that the desire to end your own is symptomatic of mental illness as well. Obviously there are rational reasons to want to (such as ending extreme pain), which is what the terminal illness requirement is meant to distinguish between.

I work in medicine and I'd argue it sometimes even gets worse when family gets involved. Lots of stories of families prolonging the patient's suffering and expecting a "miracle" that has no chances of happening.
My sweet girl tried to convince me she was fine...as we were driving to the vet. Please show mercy and let them have a gentle end.

I think it more accurate and and fairer to call it a moral standpoint rather than a religious one. There are religions that would be on the side of euthanasia and there are likely to be non-religious belief systems that are against it. Also, a person's views on these matters can differ from the official standpoint of their organised religion.

And, we are now here. Yes, we are. Impoverish the people then offer this as a solution.  Poverty often is a byproduct of physical and mental challenges (and a host of other things) so I guess this is one way to get rid of them dang Useless Eaters. Then they can say they 'helped' these desperate folks. Oh, and there are many valid reasons for someone to opt for MAID and I am not against it. However, this is the slippery slope I keep spouting about.    What the hell is happening in Canada????

that is sorta what happens when you take deaths from hundreds of different causes that would all individually still have happened, spread out across the statistics for all those hundreds of different and often horrific causes, and aggregate them into a single figure like MAID.   I have my complaints about the MAID system, but this is not a good argument.
I'd make the argument that allowing prolonged suffering is a much worse breach of it than actually killing them. Quality of life is the relevant metric. Merely being biologically alive is worthless.
The fact that people do not see the logical outcome of this line of thought is legitimately scary.

A cousin of mine died the slowest, most painful cancer-related death I've ever seen and it was known that he just wasn't going to get better quite early. I really wish no one has to go through that. If you suffer a terminal illness and your quality of life is terrible without realistic chances of healing, it's downright barbaric to ban euthanasia.

I voted for assisted suicide.  When initially asked, my choice was very clear.  No one should ever be forced to suffer.  I even watched documentaries that showed how much our current system hurt those in need. Still, when it came time to cast my ballot I felt a huge wave of doubt wash over me.  It's one thing to say it but another entirely to feel responsible for the death of another human being, even if it is desperately needed.
I read this to my family and I think I about died. I guess in that case, I needed some euthanasia.

In your opinion do you feel people are left to prolonged, debilitating states just for the sake of money so Insurance and expensive meds costs stack up?  I personally feel the undergirding foundation is greed over human dignity. In this way it would be another human alive, another dollar out of them.
I'd have no qualms. If anyone of my family asked me to do it, I wouldn't let them down.

I wish these options were available 20 years ago.  One of the last things my grandfather told to teenage me was that if he could run in front of traffic at that moment, he would.  Nobody should have to hear that from a loved one.  As a teenager, I was mad at him.  It took me a long time to understand it.

Thank you for explaining this. We had to make the hard decision yesterday to put our Toshi down. He had kidney failure and had just stopped eating completely. We didn't want him to suffer. He passed on his dad's lap with kisses and feeling loved. I didn't want him to suffer and now i know for sure we made the right choice.
That's my thinking. A human can overcome not having an arm or a leg, but a human could never overcome down syndrome.
Suicide isn't a choice, it's a breaking point. That's all anyone really needs to understand.

I have severe PTSD. My first traumatic event was at 2 and I literally have collected so much trauma since then that the only treatment left is euthanasia.  As in I've done multiple therapies with no success at all. I've been in group therapy with soldiers and because there actually is a pretrauma mind they can reference treatment can be very successful. Euthanasia should only be considered in extreme cases such as my ptsd where no treatment will work.   Such extreme cases are rare. I'm happy that this is a treatment to be honest. Ptsd kills, often violently and with a mess.  This option at least is a safe one that doesn't transfer the trauma to the family upon finding the deceased. I haven't decided personally if I want to pursue this but I am happy it is available.
My wife and I want to do this.  I hope it works out this way, having to live through her death is a terrifying idea.
yup. people are finally taking advantage of being given agency over their own passing when the time nears.
And then there's the severely defective newborn with a two day life expectancy. We don't get to help them along either

The point should be, that each person should be able to decide for themselves what is "rough enough". It's not news that people respond very differently to whatever situation they are put in, and the conditions that would still allow someone to live a meaningful and somewhat content life migh feel imbearable for another. Who are we to decide.

I'm almost sad that people are so afraid of letting terminally ill people die, that they wouldn't let them even think about doing this, because to them, these people only exist to stroke their emotions and make them feel good.

Wtf. It is like we have gone from assisted death for serious medical issues to assisted death for poverty within 2 odd years. How long before govt takes this decision making away from us and starts making these decisions for us. Next stop, forced death for anyone states finds a drain on funds?

My mom was sick with ALS, a terminal disease.  She OD'd because she knew she would be stuck with years living on a resperator, feeding tubes, etc and she feared being a fulling thinking vegetable the most out of all things in life.  So she saved up some of the meds that she was using to combat the pain and nerve issues and OD'd two days after Christmas.  I think she took a whole huge bottle of pills to make sure.  It would have been nice to say one last I love you and good bye but because of this stupid fucking country and many others she did it in secrecy so that it wouldn't implicate any of the family in case the retarded state of Florida decided to prosecute one of us for murder.

Reading back through these comments, I don't really see anyone making that point. The comments all seem veto much geared toward people with terminal illness, not merely people who "feel they've completed their lives."
They make too much money with people paying out the ass to make themselves comfortable during time when they really have no business being alive any longer.

After my mother had a stroke and was in a complete vegetative state it was decided with the doctor and family that she would not want to live like this in a bed being fed through a tube. The nurse said we could ask for morphine to "make her comfortable"  and they would give it whenever we asked.   The day nurses while the ward was busy would tell us it was too soon for more morphine.  After the shift change that night a new nurse came in and looked me in the eye and said as she was giving another dose "this is not for her but for your family...  Anytime you want more find me and ask for it"  After midnight and the floor was empty I asked her for more twice in about 15 minutes.   She died peacefully about 10 minutes later.

It's not injected. You get a prescription for either Seconal or Nembutal. Seconal is a capsule and typically a loved one will open them up and mix the powder with milk or water or something, for them to drink. Nembutal is a liquid they can just drink straight, though it's much more expensive.  Those are the only two drugs approved for use in Oregon. There is no injection option, it's all oral consumption which most patients can manage as long as they are conscious.

"Bad" is a subjective property, and badness only exists within the subjective realm. Suffering is intrinsically bad, because you cannot define the word "suffering" without the concept of badness. If it's not bad, then it isn't suffering. Death cannot be intrinsically bad, because bad is a subjective judgement, and once you are dead, you are no longer a subject.  We have an evolved instinct to resist death at all costs, which manifests itself in feelings of suffering that are aroused by thinking of death, and pain that is triggered by bodily harm which is a proxy for existential danger. But it is only the suffering itself that we experience which is actually bad. We tend to rationalise our fear of death, because it is so deeply embedded in us. But in reality, it cannot be bad.

"Bad" is a subjective property, and badness only exists within the subjective realm. Suffering is intrinsically bad, because you cannot define the word "suffering" without the concept of badness. If it's not bad, then it isn't suffering. Death cannot be intrinsically bad, because bad is a subjective judgement, and once you are dead, you are no longer a subject.  We have an evolved instinct to resist death at all costs, which manifests itself in feelings of suffering that are aroused by thinking of death, and pain that is triggered by bodily harm which is a proxy for existential danger. But it is only the suffering itself that we experience which is actually bad. We tend to rationalise our fear of death, because it is so deeply embedded in us. But in reality, it cannot be bad.

'assisted suicide', that which right-to-die advocates are actually pushing for, includes the concepts of requested-death and informed-consent, both of which are extraordinarily important legal points that must be fulfilled in all places where assisted suicide - active or passive - are allowed.

"Bad" is a subjective property, and badness only exists within the subjective realm. Suffering is intrinsically bad, because you cannot define the word "suffering" without the concept of badness. If it's not bad, then it isn't suffering. Death cannot be intrinsically bad, because bad is a subjective judgement, and once you are dead, you are no longer a subject.  We have an evolved instinct to resist death at all costs, which manifests itself in feelings of suffering that are aroused by thinking of death, and pain that is triggered by bodily harm which is a proxy for existential danger. But it is only the suffering itself that we experience which is actually bad. We tend to rationalise our fear of death, because it is so deeply embedded in us. But in reality, it cannot be bad.

The biological imperative to live is intense, and that makes your argument weak.  There are tons of people that would rather they were dead, but can't overcome that evolutionarily ingrained instinct. It should not be some kind of legal alternative to suicide imo. In the Netherlands one of the requirements for euthanasia is suffering unbearably with no hope of recovery. Two independent doctors will need to approve the request and you need to be mentally capable of making the request in the first place. Untreatable cancer is an obvious example, but it can also be Alzheimer's or dementia if you made the request while still legally competent. Now that's a bit of a dangerous one because it can be a lot harder to prove you suffer in those cases. But something like a 'regular' depression doesn't allow for euthanasia. Chronic depression can, but you need to be diagnosed with it of course.

So, I was reading about this. No doctor needs to be involved because there are no injections. It essentially just replaces all the air with nitrogen. Nitrogen is most of what you breathe anyway, and it doesn't react with your body at all with the exception of giving you the bends when you have massive changes in air pressure over a short period of time. That feeling you get when you hold your breath and feel like you really need to breathe is actually your body detecting the ph change from carbon dioxide building up in your lungs. (CO2 is acidic) Nitrogen doesn't give you that feeling, but it's also not oxygen. So, you don't even realize you are suffocating and just become gradually hypoxic over a couple of minutes and pass out. Then you die from lack of oxygen over the next couple of minutes.

You're right about six months being a bit tight, but it is still en enormous amount of suffering that can be evaded that way. Do not underestimate just how much worse terminal illnesses can get during their final stages. When I picture my dad six months before his death, I still see a person I recognize as my father. The last few months let him lose the rest of his hair and more weight than I would have thought possible. The agony also reached a previously unknown high, which too we wouldn't have though possible. He spent his last weeks on incredible doses of Valium, and was in pain even then. Six months don't sound like much, but as someone who has seen this happening I say that I'd be more than happy to take this chance should I ever be presented with it.

I have a great aunt, 94 who has been in a vegetative state for at least 3years, being kept alive by respirators, a tube used to force feed her, and a lot if nursing help - at a cost of thousands per month to her immediate family, who have lost all their wealth and most of their sanity thru this ordeal. It is painless. The pain and panic we feel when suffocating is triggered by carbon dioxide buildup in our blood, not the absence of oxygen. Being immersed in nitrogen kills you, because you need oxygen to live, but also prevents the elevated presence of carbon dioxide in your blood, so your death is peaceful.  You essentially feel light-headed, then fall asleep, and then die in your sleep.

It's not injected. You get a prescription for either Seconal or Nembutal. Seconal is a capsule and typically a loved one will open them up and mix the powder with milk or water or something, for them to drink. Nembutal is a liquid they can just drink straight, though it's much more expensive.  Those are the only two drugs approved for use in Oregon. There is no injection option, it's all oral consumption which most patients can manage as long as they are conscious.

Problem with the sound mind clause is that jurisdictions that have allowed doctor assisted suicide specifically exclude cases where the patient isn't fully cogniscent at the time of death. I took a class on biomedical ethics and this exact scenario came up. From what I remember a person with severe Alzheimer's or dementia is considered a totally separate person (ethically and philosophically) when it comes to things like advanced directives.  For example, let's assume that while you were sound of mind you gave an advanced directive that you would like physician-assisted suicide when the time comes. However, many Alzheimer's patients live content lives even while not sound of mind and with no memory of their past. It is unethical for this new person, who should be considered separate from the person they used to be, to be held to advance directives.

I watched her wait for death in the last 3 painful months, and I watched her starve to death in the last three days. I wish I didn't have those memories. I'm not religious, but if there is something after death, I hate to think she went into it with so much pain and fear. It would have been nice if she could have died on her own terms, just like she lived, bravely and independent.

Again, this is pretending a moral naturalism is true, in which it is not. Ethics is non-cognitive, non-real, and non-descriptive. It comes down to one subjects desires, based on the internal and external variables that lead to this specific arrangement of matter, producing this emergent property, which obeys the laws of physics. Of course, in the future, there may be technology to alleviates one desire, but as it stands, it's incredibly primitive (coming from someone who has trialled everything, even psychedelics like DMT etc.).

Assisted suicide should be opt-in and never opt-out. If the person is in a situation where they can't make their desires known and haven't previously made their desires known then the default is not to intervene.  It solves the problem completely.

Two important points are that it was a unanimous decision and that it was held to be unconstitutional to ban it under section 7 of the Charter.  The Supreme Court has the ability to override certain fundamental freedoms under Section 1 of the Charter, but Section 7 of the Charter is a very special part of our constitution that has never been overridden by the Supreme Court. Basically, they made their position on the matter as clear as possible. Parliament can respond with legislation, but the SCC signaled that Parliament should be on its best behaviour in legislating this issue.

The best option is the Exit Bag, and it has the advantage of being able to easy to source.  You need a large bag, a non-carbon-dioxide gas supply (helium?), a velcro strap or drawstring to seal around your neck, and a hose to connect the gas supply into your bag. You just feel increasingly light headed until you pass out, there is no panic or struggle because your body isn't detecting excess CO2, and it's relatively untraceable if your country frowns upon assisted suicide since the evidence is easy to remove and it doesn't leave easily detectable traces.

My grandfather had Alzheimer's and it didn't ever make him irrational. Losing your ability to recall memories is not the same as being unable to be rational.  When someone who needs constant assistance and has been robbed of their ability to connect with family tells you they want to die, it is of course extremely difficult. Not just because you yourself must accept that the person you knew has gone, but because you must also accept that someone you deeply care for is asking you for the one thing you cannot help them with. They are in constant and clear distress and whilst they can't recall that morning or even recognise their relatives, many often consistently express a wish to die.
You'll get over that after a few years' experience watching elderly patients suffering in pain that won't go away and can't be treated and the family won't respect their wishes to die.

I used to be for physician-assisted suicide until it was brought to my attention some of the ramifications of legalizing it.  Now I'm on the fence about the matter. Mostly it has to do with how insurance companies would handle such cases.  In the obvious first example, many life insurance companies may refuse payout to those who opt for assisted suicide.  However, this is fairly easily legislated though.   The real problem actually has to do with the health insurance companies.  If given the choice, health insurance companies might refuse payment for an expensive, yet effective, procedure hoping to drive their customers to suicide and thus saving them money.   It's a very difficult problem.  I am all for body autonomy but I am apprehensive that companies may highjack the movement for profit.

A letter alone wouldn't be sufficient in this sort of case.  It's not like some random relative can just show up with a letter and claim that Grandma totally wanted to die. Euthanasia can be part of a care plan that's drawn up when someone is diagnosed with early dementia (when they're still mentally functional enough to make decisions), so presumably there would be multiple witnesses (doctors, social workers, lawyers, etc.), and family members would likely be involved in the planning process.  Before euthanasia would actually take place, at least two doctors would have to confirm that the patient's quality of life was extremely poor.  Hospital policies generally require that the next of kin are in agreement with a DNR request so I imagine that it would be the same for a euthanasia request.

It'll actually be open to people with any grievous and irremediable medical condition (according to the Supreme Court ruling). This could include people with a terminal illness or someone with a disability or someone with a chronic condition (depression, arthritis, etc).

In Canada, no one chooses oral MAID except thespians because they have to start an IV anyway in case the oral drug doesn't work. The MAID provider (a doctor) will inject first an anixolytic (anti-anxiety to ensure the patient is calm) then one gram of propofol to stop all brain wave activity, which is already more than enough to kill the patient, then 0.2 g rocuronium to stop all muscles to ensure the heart stays stopped. Works like a damn. It's better than a natural death as with a natural death the brain remains active for over a minute after death. MAID is just yanking the PLL circuit without waiting for the hibernate file to be uploaded to the cloud server.

My intention is not to minimize the pain of these events, I've had pets die myself. I am illustrating that we as a society generally do not rank animal lives, despite the pain of losing them, on the same level as humans.  We euthanize animals, however humanely, for behavioral issues, for not having owners (two things that have always been disturbing to me), and if they are sick (or too expensive to treat) enough.  So comparing animal euthanasia to human euthanasia seems to be fallacious given that we seem to approach it from opposite ends.
starving, dehydration, low temperature fire and full conscious drowning are the worst ways to go apart from slow, methodical physical mutilation.

Yes. Especially if the patient themselves requests it and they are of sound mind, then it is not the government's place to say no. The issue is... depression fucks up your sense of meaning. It denies you hope. That is the core symptom. So every time people get depressed enough, they feel they should die. Watching someone die from a terminal illness is haunting. I'll never forget the death rattle, the way she grabbed at her throat until she couldn't breathe anymore, and the last exhale. I was hoping she would lose consciousness and just sleep, but she never did. She was awake with eyes like startled deer.  The nurse was with us but morphine wasn't administered until it was clear she was going. I think choking on the morphine is what did her in, but it was that or another day or two of abject suffering. I would much rather be euthanized than experience that agonized breathing, fighting for breath while your body can't take it anymore.

The way the IV end-of-life drug was administered in "Three Body Problems" was incredibly well done. To start it, the patient had to tap "yes" five times on an iPad. The fact that each yes was in a distinct location on the screen prevented them from doing it by accident. The patient could then do it on his own schedule. Take no obligation to complete it. and did not require the physicians to be present.

One big challenge is the straddling of federal jurisdiction (criminal liability) and provincial (health care). All of the necessary questions and implementation challenges can't be answered through crim code changes so the provinces and territories have a big role to play too.

If someone is actually in an advanced stage of disease where they would die off supports they often are actually not benefiting from the feeding tube. In instances like advanced-stage cancer the body actually reduces what it is using from food intake because it recognizes that this energy is mostly just feeding the disease. So people aren't being "starved" as their bodies are already doing that and we are forcing nutrition into them with feeding tubes. (Worked in hospice, heard the physicians explain this to families on a regular basis but I myself am not a medical professional) Also, declining use of life-prolonging treatments is not the same as physician assisted death. It's hospice-palliative care. There was never a question about the legality of hospice as people have the right to decline medical treatment if they have capacity.
Yeah, my grandfather in the UK passed away due to terminal cancer - the last months were seriously hard but there wasn't any other option.

Not sure what the procedure is in the Netherlands for  children, but I have some experience with euthanasia in the Netherlands.  When my mom was terminally I'll I downloaded some forms, my dad, sister, and I went to our gp and asked if he would be willing to carry out the euthanasia. He agreed and my mom's case was sent to a different physician to be evaluated.  After the all clear form the second physician it was up to my mom to decide the date and time in accordance to our gp's schedule. She had her casket and cremation planned so the undertaker knew what time to come.

There are some questions about the circulation of this article. Interviews with her have previously only appeared in lifestyle magazines before they started circulating today in questionable media sources like NDTV above and are now being picked up by American right-wing sites. It is very strange that this story has more foreign circulation than in the Netherlands itself, in any source, and none in any news sources. So take this story with a grain of salt, lot of red flags here and very little information over her actual medical assessment beyond her own words. And just to be clear, I'm Belgian and support the right to euthanasia, but the timing of this post after a previous post on euthanasia today in the sub that drew controversy has got me suspicious.

That sounds "easy" but you should arrange that in advance. My father (67) has a very fast progressing glioblastoma. He is in an advanced state of dementia now and doesn't know or understand most things anymore. Can't do basic self care. The patient, doctor, and parents must all agree that the conditions have been met (terminal illness, suffering, etc). An independent doctor must also confirm the conditions have been met. The doctor submits a report to a review board and the coroner. The doctor could face homicide charges if the review board determines the euthanasia did not adhere to legal requirements.

There are many practical implementation issues to sort through that go beyond the research. How will physicians be trained? What drugs will be used? Who pays? Do families have objection rights? Etc. I'm not saying there are grounds to delay indefinitely, but the short term extension sought today will help ensure these things are well thought through. It really isn't. Medical assistance in dying is a hard fought for right, and something that the Federal Government opposed all the way to the Supreme Court. Access to prescription medications in Canada does need an overhaul, but a weakness in that area doesn't mean that the right to a dignified death on one's own terms is eugenics.

As someone who works in industrial slaughter, "humane slaughter" is defined as instantaneous loss of consciousness. Meaning they're awake and alert one moment, and unconscious the next. I can't read the article, but what is new is the fact that now 1 - 12 year old children have the right to make that decision themselves. Until now, only children older than 12 had the right to make that decision. Children younger than 1, the parents still need to make the decision (although often doctors do it for them). Until now, the parents needed to make the decision for 1-12 year olds. It may sound strange to have a 8 year old decide to die, but children in this situation often have a clear picture of what awaits them and know what will happen. Though Oregon has been one of the trailblazers for both. For marijuana, we were within the first few states for decriminalization, medical, and recreational use. The Death With Dignity Act made Oregon not just the first state in the US to allow medical aid in dying, but one of the first jurisdictions in the world.

TBF, they already have Oregon to kick around for our "Death With Dignity" act.   We first passed it in '94, but it didn't fully go fully into effect until 2016 when the US Supreme Court ruled it constitutional, quashing any additional injunctions or suits. All that should matter is that the individual in question has capacity. Capacity of course includes having authentic values. For instance, an elderly person who wants to die because they no longer contribute to society does not hold an authentic value here and therefore lacks capacity. Their value is ethically indefensible because persons are not defined by how much they can produce (there is more to a person than being a production unit). As for substitute decision makers, they are required to use the previously held competent values of the person when making decision for them. Issues of abide can easily be solved by putting in proper legislation that prevents it (eg if you are a substitute decision maker think dying is best for them, perhaps you should have to provide evidence to a court how this follows their previously held competent values).

'legalizing' assisted suicide helps you regulate it.  It lets you make sure somebody who is considering these options has thoroughly explored their other options and has settled on this option, and does not change their mind for a period of weeks or months while the process is reviewed or confirmed. First off, I'm so sorry for your loss. I can't imagine being put in that situation.   As for the difference, it's just terminology even though I've heard people argue they're all essentially the same. It seems that your story is an example of passive euthanasia--a doctor withholding a treatment lets the patient die. There's also active euthanasia where a doctor administers something to kill the patient.   Physician assisted suicide, which is what OP referenced, is slightly different. It involves a doctor prescribing or suggesting something to a patient that the patient will use to end his or her life. The patient is the one who ends it technically, not the doctor's action or inaction.

The ruling is not a big deal, the court is just saying that this is a matter of legislature, not court. They aren't the ones responsible for making this legal. Physician-assisted suicide is a procedure that requires doctors, observers, a review, and the method of death must be administered by the person to die- hence it is suicide. Euthanasia is administered by others to the person who is going to die, such as in execution or eugenics.

IIRC regular asphyxia reaction is caused by presence of CO2, not lack of oxygen. Inert gas asphyxiation doesn't trigger regular distress and biological reactions. That's why inert gasses are so dangerous in industrial settings. If safety protocols fail, or worse, are ignored, and something goes wrong, people just lose consciousness and die without any warning.

what is legal in the US and Canada for assisted suicide is very different from what is available in the EU.  Canada requires verified "terminal illness" in patients, while what is available in Switzerland (and possibly some other EU countries?) to my knowledge is assisted suicide for patients with "unbearable mental or physical pain" which can include illnesses that are not considered terminal in the Americas (such as alzheimers, etc.)

Just wanted to point out that there is a subtle difference between medically assisted suicide and euthanasia. Death with dignity laws allow doctors to prescribe medications in lethal doses, but the dying person is the one who consumes it, by their own hand. First off, I'm so sorry for your loss. I can't imagine being put in that situation.   As for the difference, it's just terminology even though I've heard people argue they're all essentially the same. It seems that your story is an example of passive euthanasia--a doctor withholding a treatment lets the patient die. There's also active euthanasia where a doctor administers something to kill the patient.   Physician assisted suicide, which is what OP referenced, is slightly different. It involves a doctor prescribing or suggesting something to a patient that the patient will use to end his or her life. The patient is the one who ends it technically, not the doctor's action or inaction.

Control, mostly, at almost every level. To be clear, I don't mean that any controlling layer is actively aware of being controlling, nor malicious, nor anything but noble. Families keep a person that they don't want to lose, workplaces continue to receive those viable sources of labor, industries that serve severely disabled individuals continue to make shareholder goals. Each party gets theirs, and with no need to spend money or efforts on the social welfare necessary to, say, prevent a severely disabled person from choosing suicide over continuing to participate in society each day. There are a lot of strawman arguments made about not wanting depressed individuals to be taken advantage of, children not respecting the sanctity of their own life, and individuals generally seeking permanent solutions to temporary problems . . . but the reality is that almost all of this is addressed with proper procedures and social nets.

So an 18 year old girl that got raped and feeling suicidal is just as legitimate for it as an elderly man who is terminal. People preach suicide is never the answer, but also tacitly support the notion that many lives are just not worth living.  If I were to support this, it would only be for the most extreme cases.

She clearly knew she was sick but couldn't even keep thoughts together long enough to know why. But she knew she was ready to go and wanted death. Instead, she spent almost a year in a nursing home not even knowing where she was before she died of lung cancer. I fully agree people should be able choose to end it at that point.

My mom watched her best friend die of cancer and suffer until the very end. Also, a good friend of mines sister had cancer and it returned. Yes she was somewhat medicated but it was awful seeing her like that. I agree it should be legalized everywhere.

A mistake in this understanding is that, at least in Germany, suicide is never illegal. Anyone can dicide for any reason to end his life. It is the negative side of the right to life (not evaluating negative, rather, as the flipside fo the coin). The question here is if physicians can provide you with the tools necessary to take your life. For any medical procedure, it has to be medically necessary, which is based no scientific studies. If there is no reason to believe that the situation that causes you to want to take your life will be resolved (either because there is no medical solution for it or the rate of success is very slim), than the suicide is medically implicated and it is legal to assist as a physician in that.

My grandmother passed away last year, with the help of MAID. They observed the waiting period, and her primary care doctor met with her privately, without either my mom or myself in the room, to discuss her options.

I am a medical student in Ireland and in our ethics classes this comes up often. Usually the legal arguments that keep these laws from happening are based on the fact that people can be manipulated and pressured into ending their lives by others. The argument generally goes something like "it is impractically difficult to be sure that someone is saying they want to end their life of their own free will rather than being coerced, so suicide will not be legalised".  I am not saying I agree with this, but I just wanted to throw it into the discussion since so often this issue is painted along the lines of idiotic laws preventing the relief of suffering. I personally disagree with the above position, but I do think it is a valid counter argument that needs to be considered.

I am a medical student in Ireland and in our ethics classes this comes up often. Usually the legal arguments that keep these laws from happening are based on the fact that people can be manipulated and pressured into ending their lives by others. The argument generally goes something like "it is impractically difficult to be sure that someone is saying they want to end their life of their own free will rather than being coerced, so suicide will not be legalised".  I am not saying I agree with this, but I just wanted to throw it into the discussion since so often this issue is painted along the lines of idiotic laws preventing the relief of suffering. I personally disagree with the above position, but I do think it is a valid counter argument that needs to be considered.

As a physician who participates in MAID this is an inaccurate title.  The act of euthanasia is defined as a lethal dose of medication administered by someone other than the person who will die as a result of that administration.  This is not legal in any US state.  MAID is a process by which a patient can receive a prescription for a collection of medications that they must self administer.  Someone can help mix the medication but they cannot have someone else give it to them.  This may sound like a technicality, but it is a very important legal distinction.  It means that I have to provide informed consent that if, somehow, the medication is not successful, the patient may be in a vegetative state and persist that way until their terminal disease takes a natural course.  We can't, excuse the dark imagery here, "finish the job."
My mom had CIDP and passed away two years ago. I wish she would have had peace and not suffered. I wish I could offer you solace. I just hope you're able to go out on your own terms.

The Autism in Canada report is a precursor to a national autism strategy. 1,600 autistic individuals contributed feedback in it alongside neurotypical and autistic subject experts. Research cited stated that autistic individuals have a 7-9x higher rate of suicide than the general population.      There is hope. Many countries are moving toward national autism strategies and policy frameworks to address issues related to mental health, belonging and services. One point raised is developing more autism acceptance with the general population, rather than putting sole responsibility on the autistic individual to learn to mimic neurotypical social skills.

If we're lucky, people live long enough that their body breaks down and their quality of life gradually declines over time. For most of us, quality of life can still be pretty good into our senior years, but no matter how well we take care of our bodies there comes a point where they break down enough that quality of life is more negative than positive on a daily basis, and our pain and suffering will only continue to increase until our bodies just stop. When that happens for our pets, we accept that it's cruel to keep them in a state of pain and suffering from which they can never recover. We should have the same compassion for the humans in our lives, and let them choose to end their lives when their quality of life declines past the point where they want to keep going.

The law is pretty restrictive. It limits doctor assisted suicide to those 18 or older, who are mentally competent, and imposes a 15 day reflective period. The bill (C-14) limits access to those "suffering intolerably" and whose death is "reasonably foreseeable." It doesn't allow for advance consent for patients with degenerative disorders, either. So if you have a disease like MS, ALS, or Alzheimer's, you may suffer for years with your condition growing progressively worse until you're deemed OK to die. The bill doesn't go nearly far enough, IMO.

I am a medical student in Ireland and in our ethics classes this comes up often. Usually the legal arguments that keep these laws from happening are based on the fact that people can be manipulated and pressured into ending their lives by others. The argument generally goes something like "it is impractically difficult to be sure that someone is saying they want to end their life of their own free will rather than being coerced, so suicide will not be legalised".  I am not saying I agree with this, but I just wanted to throw it into the discussion since so often this issue is painted along the lines of idiotic laws preventing the relief of suffering. I personally disagree with the above position, but I do think it is a valid counter argument that needs to be considered.

IIRC regular asphyxia reaction is caused by presence of CO2, not lack of oxygen. Inert gas asphyxiation doesn't trigger regular distress and biological reactions. That's why inert gasses are so dangerous in industrial settings. If safety protocols fail, or worse, are ignored, and something goes wrong, people just lose consciousness and die without any warning.

My best friend's grandma spent around 2 or 3 weeks in a hospice where they pumped her full of medication to "help her deal with the process" (of dying). It took an exhaustive emotional toll on everyone to drag her death out that long. She was going to die. Everyone knew she didn't have much longer to live. The inevitable was right around the corner. The ruling is not a big deal, the court is just saying that this is a matter of legislature, not court. They aren't the ones responsible for making this legal. Physician-assisted suicide is a procedure that requires doctors, observers, a review, and the method of death must be administered by the person to die- hence it is suicide. Euthanasia is administered by others to the person who is going to die, such as in execution or eugenics.

The good (??) news is that if you were diagnosed with ALS, you would certainly be given access to MAID drugs if you wanted them and if they were legal where you live. What's interesting to me is that my mom had a DNR order. She died in her car, was resuscitated by paramedics, and brought to a hospital. Problem is that she had been dead for probably half an hour. She was brain dead. We took her off life support. And she was breathing on her own, and it was awful. We didn't feed her or give her water until she died a few days later.  How is that any different? She'd be alive today in a PVS if we had allowed it, but we killed her.  What's more is that my own mom was a nurse and told me during her career this was pretty common.

I am a medical student in Ireland and in our ethics classes this comes up often. Usually the legal arguments that keep these laws from happening are based on the fact that people can be manipulated and pressured into ending their lives by others. The argument generally goes something like "it is impractically difficult to be sure that someone is saying they want to end their life of their own free will rather than being coerced, so suicide will not be legalised".  I am not saying I agree with this, but I just wanted to throw it into the discussion since so often this issue is painted along the lines of idiotic laws preventing the relief of suffering. I personally disagree with the above position, but I do think it is a valid counter argument that needs to be considered.

First of all, assisted suicide is legal for ages in Germany, the restriction here was for comercial assisted suicide. Such an assisted suicide is a medical procedure, which has a thightly knit legal enviornment around it that demands that medical procedures are only done when necessary and that alternative treatments should be used. Every doctor is bound by their professional rules as well. The constitutional court only permitted only the general practice that all kinds of comercial assisted suicides are illegal, that doesn't mean that they said that everyone can have it without restrictions. This was only a decision about the current legal sollution, not if other solutions that limit these assistances to terminal cases or cases with very little hope of betterment would be illegal as well.

It is in the temporal nature of our relationships with our dogs and cats, and most any animal, that we will face this moment with them.   We must remain strong and make the sometimes heart-wrenching decisions during their transition that they need us to make, because they cannot make them for themselves.   They cannot be left to suffering.  And in the end, we must grieve their loss in our own way.  The depths of grief are a direct reflection of the depths of love that you felt. In NJ, and my Mom went through it a few years back. I expect that you can find someone who has experience and will help you with the process. Even if your mother decides not to go through with it, the sense of control is very worth it. The difference in my mother's state of mind before and after she had that control was night and day.  I wish you and your mom the best.

of course. but other people don't have the right to decide what you can and can't do with your own body. and when that right is taken away from you - no matter the context - your rights are violated and your autonomy is lost. it's unjust. nor is it fair or just to make someone suffer for exercising control over their own body. people are going to take their own lives anyway, so we may as well give them a dignified and comfortable way to do it. it may not be a pleasant truth, but it is the truth. that said, we should also be actively working to improve the world around us so that fewer people choose to exercise that inalienable choice in the first place.

Yeah, my grandma's euthanasia was in that sense also an eye opener for me. The trauma on families can be far worse when the person does it themselves. Seeing pieces of your family members is probably one of the most traumatic things a person can live. I was present when my uncle died. The whole family sat by his bed in the hospital while he slowly stopped breathing over a matter of hours. That was the actual process of dying. He had been declining for months and had angrily threatened that he would die if my mother took him out of his home to the hospital.  A few months later, my cat was diagnosed with cancer. I had him put down at home. A pair of vets came to my house, gently injected him while he lay in his bed, and he sighed peacefully and stopped breathing a moment later. It made me think, why couldn't this have been the way for my uncle? Why did it have to be a fight and then a long vigil waiting for him to die?
